abstract.title: EPUB Publications 3.1
abstract.para: EPUB is an interchange and delivery format for digital publications based on XML and Web Standards.

section.title: Purpose and Scope
section.para: This specification, EPUB 3.1, defines a distribution and interchange format standard for digital publications and documents. EPUB® defines a means of representing, packaging and encoding structured and semantically enhanced Web content — including HTML5, CSS, SVG and other resources — for distribution in a single-file format.

EPUB has been widely adopted as the format for digital books (eBooks), and these specifications significantly increase the format's capabilities in order to better support a wider range of publication requirements, including complex layouts, rich media and interactivity, and global typography features. The expectation is that EPUB 3.1 will be utilized for a broad range of content, including books, magazines and educational, professional and scientific publications.

EPUB 3.1 is modular in nature, consisting of a family of specifications that define the core features and functionality of the standard. This specification is the primary entry point to standard, but does not provide details about how to create or consume EPUB Publications. The details of the standard are defined in the family of specifications defined in . An index to key concepts and definitions is provided in .

For those looking for a more descriptive overview of EPUB 3.1, the informative provides a general introduction to the standard. A list of technical changes from EPUB 3.0.1, the previous version of the standard, is also available in the informative .

listitem.para: EPUB Publications 3.1 , which defines the semantics and overarching conformance requirements for EPUB Publications, including the requirements for each of the content and the profiles of XHTML, SVG and CSS.
EPUB Media Overlays 3.1 , which defines a format and a processing model for synchronization of text and audio.
EPUB Open Container Format (OCF) 3.1 , which defines a file format and processing model for encapsulating a set of related resources into a single-file (ZIP) .
EPUB Canonical Fragment Identifiers (epubcfi) , which defines a standardized method for referencing arbitrary content within an EPUB Publication through the use of fragment identifiers.
Alternate Style Tags , which defines a pattern for tagging alternate style sheets using microformats.
